q: Who was the founder of the Mughal Empire in India?
desc: Babur founded the Mughal Empire in 1526 after defeating Ibrahim Lodhi at the First Battle of Panipat.

q: Which technology did Babur introduce in Indian warfare?
desc: Babur introduced the use of gunpowder and artillery in Indian battles.

q: Whom did Babur defeat in the First Battle of Panipat (1526)?
desc: Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodhi in 1526, marking the beginning of the Mughal Empire.

q: The Battle of Khanwa (1527) was fought between Babur and:
desc: Babur defeated Rana Sanga (Sangram Singh) at the Battle of Khanwa in 1527.

q: Who was defeated by Babur in the Battle of Chanderi (1528)?
desc: Medini Rai of Chanderi was defeated by Babur in 1528.

q: Which battle did Babur fight against Mahmud Lodi?
desc: The Battle of Ghagra in 1529 was fought by Babur against Mahmud Lodi.

q: In which language did Babur write his memoirs, Tuzuk-i-Baburi?
desc: Babur wrote Tuzuk-i-Baburi in his native Turkish language.

q: What title did Babur adopt after declaring Jehad?
desc: Babur declared Jehad and took the title ‘Ghazi’ meaning a warrior of faith.

q: Where was Babur originally buried after his death in 1530?
desc: Babur was first buried at Aram Bagh in Agra, later moved to Kabul.

q: Which place became Babur’s final resting place?
desc: Babur’s body was later shifted to Bagh-e Babun in Kabul, Afghanistan.

q: What was the name of the second capital built by Humayun in Delhi?
desc: Humayun built Dinpanah in Delhi as his second capital.

q: Who defeated Humayun in the Battle of Chausa (1539)?
desc: Sher Shah Suri defeated Humayun in the Battle of Chausa in 1539.

q: In which battle was Humayun again defeated by Sher Shah Suri in 1540?
desc: Humayun was decisively defeated by Sher Shah Suri in the Battle of Kannauj in 1540.

q: How many years did Humayun spend in exile after his defeat?
desc: Humayun spent 15 years in exile after being defeated by Sher Shah Suri.

q: Who helped Humayun to recapture the Mughal throne in 1555?
desc: Humayun was assisted by Bairam Khan in regaining the throne in 1555.

q: How did Humayun die in 1556?
desc: Humayun died after accidentally falling from the stairs of his library.

q: Who wrote the book 'Humayun-nama'?
desc: Humayun-nama was written by Humayun's half-sister Gulbadan Begum.

q: At what age did Akbar become emperor?
desc: Akbar was coronated as emperor at the age of 14.

q: Who defeated Hemu in the Second Battle of Panipat (1556)?
desc: Akbar, with help from Bairam Khan, defeated Hemu in 1556.

q: Which Mughal officer helped Akbar in early victories and guidance?
desc: Bairam Khan was Akbar’s regent and guided him during his early reign.

q: Who ruled Malwa when Akbar conquered it in 1561?
desc: Baz Bahadur was defeated by Akbar when Malwa was annexed in 1561.

q: Who ruled Garh-Katanga when Akbar invaded it?
desc: Rani Durgawati was the ruler of Garh-Katanga and fought bravely against Akbar.

q: In which year did Akbar conquer Chittor?
desc: Chittor was captured by Akbar in 1568 after a prolonged siege.

q: Which Rajput fort did Akbar conquer in 1569?
desc: Akbar captured Ranthambhor Fort in 1569 as part of his Rajput campaigns.

q: The Battle of Haldighati (1576) was fought between Akbar and:
desc: Rana Pratap resisted Mughal expansion and fought Akbar in the Battle of Haldighati.

q: When did Akbar conquer Kashmir?
desc: Akbar annexed Kashmir into the Mughal Empire in 1586.

q: Which region did Akbar annex in 1593?
desc: Sindh was conquered by Akbar in 1593, expanding Mughal rule in the northwest.

q: Which fort was captured by Akbar in 1603?
desc: Asirgarh Fort was the last major conquest of Akbar in 1603.

q: Where is Buland Darwaza located?
desc: Buland Darwaza was constructed at Fatehpur Sikri after Akbar’s victory over Gujarat in 1572.

q: Which victory led Akbar to build Buland Darwaza?
desc: The gateway was built to commemorate Akbar’s victory over Gujarat in 1572.

q: Who was Harkha Bai?
desc: Harkha Bai was Akbar’s wife and the daughter of Rajput ruler Bharmal.

q: Who was the first Englishman to visit Akbar’s court?
desc: Ralph Fitch visited Akbar’s court in 1585 and was the first Englishman to do so.

q: When did Akbar abolish the Jaziyah tax?
desc: Akbar abolished the discriminatory Jaziyah tax on non-Muslims in 1564.

q: What does Sulh-i-Kul mean?
desc: Sulh-i-Kul was Akbar’s principle promoting religious tolerance and peace among all religions.

q: Where was the Ibadat Khana built by Akbar?
desc: The Ibadat Khana or Hall of Prayer was constructed at Fatehpur Sikri by Akbar.

q: In which year did Akbar issue the 'Degree of Infallibility'?
desc: Akbar issued the 'Degree of Infallibility' in 1579, asserting his authority in religious matters.

q: What was the name of Akbar’s religious order?
desc: Akbar formulated Din-i-Ilahi in 1582, blending elements of various religions.

q: Who was the first to join Din-i-Ilahi?
desc: Birbal was the first courtier to accept Akbar’s religious order, Din-i-Ilahi.

q: What was the name of Akbar’s land revenue system?
desc: Akbar's land revenue system was called the Todar Mal Bandobast or Zabti System.

q: Which system was used for organizing the Mughal nobility and army?
desc: The Mansabdari system organized ranks and responsibilities within the Mughal army and bureaucracy.

q: Who among the following was NOT one of Akbar’s Navratnas?
desc: Sher Shah Suri was not one of Akbar’s nine jewels (Navratnas).

q: Who among Akbar’s Navratnas was known for music?
desc: Tansen was a legendary musician and one of the Navratnas in Akbar’s court.

q: Who wrote the 'Akbarnama'?
desc: Abul Fazal was a historian and courtier who wrote Akbarnama and Ain-i-Akbari.

q: Which Sikh Guru was executed by Jahangir?
desc: Jahangir ordered the execution of Guru Arjan Dev in 1606, the fifth Sikh Guru.

q: Which place did Jahangir lose to Persia in 1622?
desc: Jahangir lost Kandahar to the Safavids of Persia in 1622, a major failure of his reign.

q: What title was conferred upon Mehr-un-Nisa after marrying Jahangir?
desc: Mehr-un-Nisa was titled 'Nurjahan' after marrying Jahangir in 1611.

q: Which justice device did Jahangir set up at Agra Fort?
desc: Jahangir established the Zanjir-i-Adal, a chain of justice for the public to seek redressal.

q: Which English ambassador visited Jahangir's court?
desc: Sir Thomas Roe was sent by King James I and visited Jahangir’s court to seek trade rights.

q: Which painter was famous in Jahangir’s court?
desc: Ustad Mansur was known for naturalistic and animal paintings during Jahangir’s reign.

q: Which European traveler visited Jahangir’s court along with Hawkins?
desc: Captain Hawkins and Sir Thomas Roe were notable English visitors to Jahangir’s court.

q: Who annexed Ahmadnagar during the Mughal rule?
desc: Shahjahan annexed Ahmadnagar, expanding Mughal control in the Deccan.

q: When did Shahjahan secure Kandahar from Persia?
desc: Shahjahan reclaimed Kandahar from Persia in 1639, though it was later lost again.

q: Which two South Indian kingdoms accepted Shahjahan’s overlordship?
desc: Bijapur and Golconda accepted Shahjahan's suzerainty without military resistance.

q: Who among these was a French traveler to Shahjahan’s court?
desc: Francois Bernier was a French physician and traveler who visited Shahjahan’s court.

q: Which Mughal emperor built the Taj Mahal?
desc: Shahjahan built the Taj Mahal in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

q: Which Mughal monument is known as the 'Pearl Mosque'?
desc: Moti Masjid, meaning 'Pearl Mosque', was built by Shahjahan in Agra.

q: Which Mughal emperor’s reign is known as the Golden Age of architecture?
desc: Shahjahan’s reign is considered the Golden Age of Mughal architecture due to monuments like the Taj Mahal and Red Fort.

q: Who became emperor after the Mughal war of succession in 1658?
desc: Aurangzeb emerged victorious after defeating his brothers Dara, Shuja, and Murad in a war of succession.

q: Which region saw a Jat peasant rebellion during Aurangzeb’s reign?
desc: The Jat peasantry in Mathura rebelled during Aurangzeb’s rule.

q: Which Sikh Guru was executed by Aurangzeb?
desc: Guru Tegh Bahadur, the ninth Sikh Guru, was executed by Aurangzeb in 1675.

q: Which peasant group rebelled in Punjab during Aurangzeb’s reign?
desc: The Satnamis, a peasant sect, rebelled in Punjab against Aurangzeb’s rule.

q: The annexation of which region in 1658 led to a Mughal-Rajput rift?
desc: The annexation of Marwar after the death of Raja Jaswant Singh led to a rift with Rajputs.

q: Which Mughal ruler achieved the greatest territorial extent of the empire?
desc: The Mughal Empire reached its greatest territorial extent under Aurangzeb.

q: Aurangzeb’s empire stretched from Kashmir to which southern city?
desc: Aurangzeb’s empire extended from Kashmir in the north to Jinji in the south.

q: Which tax did Aurangzeb reimpose in 1679?
desc: Aurangzeb reimposed the Jaziya tax on non-Muslims in 1679.

q: What was Aurangzeb also known as due to his austere lifestyle?
desc: Aurangzeb was known as 'Zinda Pir' or the living saint because of his simple lifestyle.

q: In which year did Aurangzeb conquer Bijapur?
desc: Aurangzeb conquered Bijapur in 1686, expanding Mughal rule in the Deccan.

q: Which Deccan state did Aurangzeb conquer in 1687?
desc: Aurangzeb captured the rich kingdom of Golconda in 1687.

q: What monument did Aurangzeb build at Aurangabad?
desc: Bibi Ka Maqbara was built by Aurangzeb in memory of his wife Rabia-ud-Daurani.

q: Where is the Badshahi Mosque, built by Aurangzeb, located?
desc: The Badshahi Mosque, a grand Mughal structure, was built by Aurangzeb in Lahore.

q: Which mosque did Aurangzeb build inside the Red Fort?
desc: Aurangzeb built the Moti Masjid (Pearl Mosque) inside the Red Fort, Delhi.

q: Which of these was NOT a cause of Mughal decline?
desc: The Mughal Empire declined due to weak successors, not strong ones.

q: Who invaded India in 1739, weakening the Mughal Empire?
desc: Nadir Shah invaded Delhi in 1739 and carried off immense wealth, accelerating Mughal decline.

q: Which ruler repeatedly invaded India after Nadir Shah?
desc: Ahmad Shah Abdali invaded India multiple times after Nadir Shah’s invasion.

q: What was the religious policy of Aurangzeb often criticized for?
desc: Aurangzeb's strict Islamic orthodoxy alienated many and contributed to the empire’s decline.

q: What was the main administrative crisis during Mughal decline?
desc: The Jagirdari system collapsed due to over-assignment of jagirs and poor revenue realization.

q: Which regional power grew strong during Mughal decline?
desc: The Marathas emerged as a dominant power after Aurangzeb’s prolonged Deccan campaigns.

q: Who founded the Sur Dynasty?
desc: Farid, later known as Sher Shah Suri, founded the Sur Dynasty after defeating Humayun.

q: Who gave the title 'Sher Shah' to Farid?
desc: Bahar Khan Lohani, the Afghan ruler of Bihar, gave the title 'Sher Shah' to Farid.

q: Which coin was introduced by Sher Shah Suri?
desc: Sher Shah introduced the silver coin called 'Rupaya', the predecessor to modern Rupee.

q: What copper coin did Sher Shah Suri issue?
desc: The copper coin introduced by Sher Shah Suri was called the Dam.

q: Where is Sher Shah’s tomb located?
desc: Sher Shah’s tomb is a grand structure located in Sasaram, Bihar.

q: What city did Sher Shah Suri build on the Yamuna River?
desc: Sher Shah built a new city at the site of present-day Purana Qila in Delhi.

q: What architectural legacy did Sher Shah leave in Delhi?
desc: Sher Shah began construction of Purana Qila in Delhi, later completed by Humayun.

q: Which dynasty ruled between Humayun’s exile and restoration?
desc: The Sur Dynasty ruled during Humayun’s exile from India before his restoration.

q: Which religious practice did Aurangzeb forbid?
desc: Aurangzeb forbade the practice of Sati as part of his religious policy.
